data: Measurements are reported of the proton and deuteron spin structure functions g 1 p and g 1 d at beam energies of 29.1, 16.2, and 9.7 GeV, and g 2 p and g 2 d at a beam energy of 29.1 GeV. The integrals Γ p=∫ 0 1 g 1 p (x, Q 2) d x and Γ d=∫ 0 1 g 1 d (x, Q 2) d x were evaluated at fixed Q 2= 3 (GeV/c) 2 using the full data set to yield Γ p= 0.132±0.003 (stat)±0.009 (syst) and Γ d= 0.047±0.003±0.006. The Q 2 dependence of the ratio g 1/F 1 was studied and found to be small for Q 2> 1 (GeV/c) 2. Within experimental precision the g 2 data are well described by the twist-2 contribution, g 2 WW. Twist-3 matrix elements were extracted and compared to theoretical predictions. The asymmetry A 2 was measured and found to be significantly smaller than the positivity limit R for both proton and deuteron targets. A 2 p is found to be positive and inconsistent with zero. Measurements of g 1 in the resonance region show …
Measurements of the proton and deuteron spin structure functions  and

K Abe and T Akagi and PL Anthony and R Antonov and RG Arnold and T Averett and HR Band and JM Bauer and H Borel and PE Bosted and Vincent Breton and J Button-Shafer and JP Chen and TE Chupp and J Clendenin and C Comptour and KP Coulter and D Crabb and M Daoudi and D Day and FS Dietrich and J Dunne and H Dutz and R Erbacher and J Fellbaum and A Feltham and H Fonvieille and E Frlez and D Garvey and R Gearhart and J Gomez and P Grenier and KA Griffioen and S Hoibraten and EW Hughes and C Hyde-Wright and JR Johnson and D Kawall and A Klein and SE Kuhn and M Kuriki and R Lindgren and TJ Liu and RM Lombard-Nelsen and J Marroncle and T Maruyama and XK Maruyama and J McCarthy and W Meyer and Z-E Meziani and R Minehart and J Mitchell and J Morgenstern and GG Petratos and R Pitthan and D Pocanic and C Prescott and R Prepost and P Raines and B Raue and D Reyna and A Rijllart and Y Roblin and LS Rochester and SE Rock and OA Rondon and I Sick and LC Smith and TB Smith and M Spengos and F Staley and P Steiner and S St Lorant and LM Stuart and F Suekane and ZM Szalata and H Tang and Y Terrien and T Usher and D Walz and F Wesselmann and JL White and K Witte and CC Young and B Youngman and H Yuta and G Zapalac and B Zihlmann and D Zimmermann and E143 Collaboration

We report on the first measurement of the spin-dependent structure function g 1 d of the deuteron in the deep inelastic scattering of polarised muons off polarised deuterons, in the kinematical range 0.006< x< 0.6, 1 GeV 2< Q 2< 30 GeV 2. The first moment, Γ 1 d= ʃ 0 1 g 1 d d x= 0.023±0.020 (stat.)±0.015 (syst.), is smaller than the prediction of the Ellis-Jaffe sum rules. Using earlier measurements of g 1 p, we infer the first moment of the spin-dependent neutron structure function g 1 n. The difference Γ 1 p− Γ 1 n= 0.20±0.05 (stat.)±0.04 (syst.) agrees with the prediction of the Bjorken sum rule, Γ 1 p− Γ 1 n= 0.191±0.002.
Measurement of the spin-dependent structure function g1 (x) of the deuteron

Sever and P Shanahan and G Smirnov and A Staude and A Steinmetz and H Stuhrmann and KM Teichert and F Tessarotto and W Thiel and S Trentalange and Y Tzamouranis and M Velasco and J Vogt and R Voss

We have measured the ratio g 1 p F 1 p over the range 0.029< x< 0.8 and 1.3< Q 2< 10 (G e V/c) 2 using deep-inelastic scattering of polarized electrons from polarized ammonia. An evaluation of the integral∫ 0 1 g 1 p (x, Q 2) dx at fixed Q 2= 3 (G e V/c) 2 yields 0.127±0.004 (stat)±0.010 (syst), in agreement with previous experiments, but well below the Ellis-Jaffe sum rule prediction of 0.160±0.006. In the quark-parton model, this implies Δ q= 0.27±0.10.
Precision Measurement of the Proton Spin Structure Function

K Abe and T Akagi and PL Anthony and R Antonov and RG Arnold and T Averett and HR Band and JM Bauer and H Borel and PE Bosted and Vincent Breton and J Button-Shafer and JP Chen and TE Chupp and J Clendenin and C Comptour and KP Coulter and D Crabb and M Daoudi and D Day and FS Dietrich and J Dunne and H Dutz and R Erbacher and J Fellbaum and A Feltham and H Fonvieille and E Frlez and D Garvey and R Gearhart and J Gomez and P Grenier and KA Griffioen and S Hoibraten and EW Hughes and C Hyde-Wright and JR Johnson and D Kawall and A Klein and SE Kuhn and M Kuriki and R Lindgren and TJ Liu and RM Lombard-Nelsen and J Marroncle and T Maruyama and XK Maruyama and J McCarthy and W Meyer and Z-E Meziani and R Minehart and J Mitchell and J Morgenstern and GG Petratos and R Pitthan and D Pocanic and C Prescott and R Prepost and P Raines and B Raue and D Reyna and A Rijllart and Y Roblin and LS Rochester and SE Rock and OA Rondon and I Sick and LC Smith and TB Smith and M Spengos and F Staley and P Steiner and S St Lorant and LM Stuart and F Suekane and ZM Szalata and H Tang and Y Terrien and T Usher and D Walz and JL White and K Witte and CC Young and B Youngman and H Yuta and G Zapalac and B Zihlmann and D Zimmermann and E143 Collaboration

We report on a high-statistics measurement of the deuteron spin structure function g 1 d at a beam energy of 29 GeV in the kinematic range 0.029< x< 0.8 and 1< Q 2< 10 (GeV/c) 2. The integral γ 1 d=∫ 1 g 1 d dx evaluated at fixed Q 2= 3 (GeV/c) 2 gives 0.042±0.003 (stat)±0.004 (syst). Combining this result with our earlier measurement of g 1 p, we find γ 1 p− γ 1 n= 0.163±0.010 (stat)±0.016 (syst), which agrees with the prediction of the Bjorken sum rule with O (α s 3) corrections, γ 1 p− γ 1 n= 0.171±0.008. We find the quark contribution to the proton helicity to be Δ q= 0.30±0.06.
Precision Measurement of the Deuteron Spin Structure Function

The structure functions g1p and g1n have been measured over the range 0.014<x<0.9 and 1<Q2<40 GeV2 using deep-inelastic scattering of 48 GeV longitudinally polarized electrons from polarized protons and deuterons. We find that the Q2 dependence of g1p (g1n) at fixed x is very similar to that of the spin-averaged structure function F1p (F1n ). From an NLO QCD fit to all available data we find Γ1p−Γ1n=0.176±0.003±0.007 at Q2=5 GeV2, in agreement with the Bjorken sum rule prediction of 0.182±0.005.
Measurements of the Q2-dependence of the proton and neutron spin structure functions g1p and g1n

PL Anthony and RG Arnold and T Averett and HR Band and MC Berisso and H Borel and PE Bosted and Stephen L Bueltmann and M Buenerd and T Chupp and S Churchwell and GR Court and D Crabb and D Day and P Decowski and P DePietro and R Erbacher and R Erickson and A Feltham and H Fonvieille and E Frlez and R Gearhart and V Ghazikhanian and J Gomez and KA Griffioen and C Harris and MA Houlden and EW Hughes and CE Hyde-Wright and G Igo and S Incerti and J Jensen and JR Johnson and PM King and Yu G Kolomensky and SE Kuhn and R Lindgren and RM Lombard-Nelsen and J Marroncle and J McCarthy and P McKee and W Meyer and GS Mitchell and J Mitchell and M Olson and S Penttila and GA Peterson and GG Petratos and R Pitthan and D Pocanic and R Prepost and C Prescott and LM Qin and BA Raue and D Reyna and LS Rochester and S Rock and OA Rondon-Aramayo and F Sabatie and I Sick and T Smith and L Sorrell and F Staley and S St Lorant and LM Stuart and Z Szalata and Y Terrien and A Tobias and L Todor and T Toole and S Trentalange and D Walz and RC Welsh and FR Wesselmann and TR Wright and CC Young and M Zeier and H Zhu and B Zihlmann and E155 Collaboration

We report on precision measurements of the elastic cross section for electron-proton scattering performed in Hall C at Jefferson Lab. The measurements were made at 28 distinct kinematic settings covering a range in momentum transfer of 0.4< Q 2< 5.5 (GeV∕ c) 2. These measurements represent a significant contribution to the world’s cross section data set in the Q 2 range, where a large discrepancy currently exists between the ratio of electric to magnetic proton form factors extracted from previous cross section measurements and that recently measured via polarization transfer in Hall A at Jefferson Lab. This data set shows good agreement with previous cross section measurements, indicating that if a heretofore unknown systematic error does exist in the cross section measurements, then it is intrinsic to all such measurements.

Among the most fundamental observables of nucleon structure, electromagnetic form factors are a crucial benchmark for modern calculations describing the strong interaction dynamics of the nucleon’s quark constituents; indeed, recent proton data have attracted intense theoretical interest. In this Letter, we report new measurements of the proton electromagnetic form factor ratio using the recoil polarization method, at momentum transfers Q 2= 5.2, 6.7, and 8.5 GeV 2. By extending the range of Q 2 for which G E p is accurately determined by more than 50%, these measurements will provide significant constraints on models of nucleon structure in the nonperturbative regime.
Recoil Polarization Measurements of the Proton Electromagnetic Form Factor Ratio to

Experimental values of He 3 (He 4) elastic structure functions up to momentum transfer q 2= 4.0 (2.4)(G e V/c) 2 are presented. They are compared to calculations using three-and four-body wave functions and to asymptotic models.
Elastic Electron Scattering from He 3 and He 4 at High Momentum Transfer
RG Arnold and BT Chertok and Stephen Rock and WP Schütz and ZM Szalata and D Day and JS McCarthy and F Martin and BA Mecking and I Sick and G Tamas

New measurements are reported on the deuteron spin structure function g 1 d. These results were obtained from deep inelastic scattering of 48.3 GeV electrons on polarized deuterons in the kinematic range 0.01< x< 0.9 and 1< Q 2< 40 (GeV/c) 2. These are the first high dose electron scattering data obtained using lithium deuteride (6 Li 2 H) as the target material. Extrapolations of the data were performed to obtain moments of g 1 d, including Γ 1 d, and the net quark polarization ΔΣ.
Measurement of the deuteron spin structure function g1d (x) for 1 (GeV/c) 2< Q2< 40 (GeV/c) 2

The use of scaling and the application of dimensional analysis have been important tools for the development of new insights in physics. For exam ple, they have been widely used in the fields of solid-state and atomic physics-with particular emphasis on electron-atom scattering and neu tron scattering from liquids. Here the structure of the constituents is quite well understood and so the details of scaling, or deviation from scaling, present useful perspectives about the reaction mechanism and the dynamics of the interacting system. In the last twenty years, both theor etical and experimental work in studying scaling phenomena have been extended to higher energy and momentum transfer, a regime where nuclei and nucleons are the many-body systems under investigation. In this area it is not only information about the dynamics that is being sought, but also the nature and underlying structure of the bound …
